semantic_title: Documentation of Complications of Care - Provider Documentation and Cause-Effect Relationship
section_path: Section I > A. Conventions > 16. Documentation of Complications of Care

content.full_text: Code assignment is based on the provider's documentation of the relationship between the condition and the care or procedure, unless otherwise instructed by the classification. The guideline extends to any complications of care, regardless of the chapter the code is located in. It is important to note that not all conditions that occur during or following medical care or surgery are classified as complications. There must be a cause-and-effect relationship between the care provided and the condition, and the documentation must support that the condition is clinically significant. It is not necessary for the provider to explicitly document the term "complication." For example, if the condition alters the course of the surgery as documented in the operative report, then it would be appropriate to report a complication code. Query the provider for clarification if the documentation is not clear as to the relationship between the condition and the care or procedure. (Evidence: pg no: 17, L49-L59)
content.summary: Establishes requirements for coding complications of care based on provider documentation of cause-and-effect relationships and clinical significance (Evidence: pg no: 17, L49-L59)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code assignment is based on the provider's documentation of the relationship between the condition and the care or procedure (Evidence: pg no: 17, L49-L50)
detailed_rules.explanation: The provider must document a clear relationship between the medical care/procedure and the resulting condition for it to be coded as a complication (Evidence: pg no: 17, L49-L50)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Not all conditions that occur during or following medical care or surgery are classified as complications (Evidence: pg no: 17, L51-L52)
detailed_rules.explanation: Temporal association alone is insufficient; there must be a documented cause-and-effect relationship between the care and the condition (Evidence: pg no: 17, L51-L53)

detailed_rules.rule_text: The condition must be clinically significant (Evidence: pg no: 17, L53)
detailed_rules.explanation: The complication must have clinical significance, meaning it affects patient care, treatment, or outcomes (Evidence: pg no: 17, L53)

detailed_rules.rule_text: It is not necessary for the provider to explicitly document the term "complication" (Evidence: pg no: 17, L53-L54)
detailed_rules.explanation: The provider does not need to use the specific word "complication" if the documentation clearly establishes the cause-and-effect relationship and clinical significance (Evidence: pg no: 17, L53-L54)
